channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Statue Of Scopes Trial Lawyer Sparks Debate In Tennessee
item.description: July 12, 2017 - In 1925, the Scopes Trial sparked national debates about creationism and secularism, and put Dayton, Tenn., on the map. Now another debate is happening in Dayton about whether it's appropriate to memorialize the secular side with a statue.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - In 1925, the Scopes Trial sparked national debates about creationism and secularism, and put Dayton, Tenn., on the map. Now another debate is happening in Dayton about whether it's appropriate to memorialize the secular side with a statue. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/12/536887930/statue-of-scopes-trial-lawyer-sparks-debate-in-tennessee

item.title: Took The Wrong Medicine By Mistake? Study Finds Such Errors Are On The Rise
item.description: July 12, 2017 - A study analyzing data from poison control centers finds that the rate of serious medication errors outside health care settings doubled between 2000 and 2012.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - A study analyzing data from poison control centers finds that the rate of serious medication errors outside health care settings doubled between 2000 and 2012. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536519077/took-the-wrong-medicine-by-mistake-study-finds-such-errors-are-on-the-rise

item.title: Massive Iceberg Breaks Free In Antarctica
item.description: July 12, 2017 - Scientists say the iceberg is one of the largest seen by satellites. But the full implications of its separation off remain to be seen.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - Scientists say the iceberg is one of the largest seen by satellites. But the full implications of its separation off remain to be seen. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/12/536818782/massive-iceberg-breaks-free-in-antarctica

item.title: Video: Japan Created Easy-To-Swallow Foods To Prevent Senior Choking Deaths
item.description: July 12, 2017 - In NPR's Elise Tries series, correspondent Elise Hu tries out different experiences in East Asia. In rapidly aging Japan, an edible innovation is helping seniors enjoy meals without fear of choking.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - In NPR's Elise Tries series, correspondent Elise Hu tries out different experiences in East Asia. In rapidly aging Japan, an edible innovation is helping seniors enjoy meals without fear of choking. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/07/12/532716164/video-japan-created-easy-to-swallow-foods-to-prevent-senior-choking-deaths

item.title: Macron Got A Lot Wrong About Africa ... But Made One Good Point
item.description: July 11, 2017 - In answering a reporter's question, the French president characterized Africa as a continent of failing states with high birth rates. Viviane Rutabingwa shares her perspective.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - In answering a reporter's question, the French president characterized Africa as a continent of failing states with high birth rates. Viviane Rutabingwa shares her perspective. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/11/536445457/macron-got-a-lot-wrong-about-africa-but-made-one-good-point

item.title: Web Comic: The Scientist Who Escaped Aleppo
item.description:
July 11, 2017 - It was a harrowing journey. Nedal Said made a new life in Germany — and found what he'd always been looking for.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/11/526777542/web-comic-the-scientist-who-escaped-aleppo

item.title: With Caviar, Clay, and Turkey Feathers, Saving Lake Sturgeon From Extinction
item.description: July 11, 2017 - Lake sturgeon have been around since the dinosaurs, and they can live as long as humans, or longer. Overfishing and pollution has decimated populations, but biologists are learning to help them breed.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - Lake sturgeon have been around since the dinosaurs, and they can live as long as humans, or longer. Overfishing and pollution has decimated populations, but biologists are learning to help them breed. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/11/536595541/with-caviar-clay-and-turkey-feathers-saving-lake-sturgeon-from-extinction

item.title: Reading, Writing And Fracking? What The Oil Industry Teaches Oklahoma Students
item.description: July 11, 2017 - Oklahoma's oil industry is spending millions on science lessons for public schools. But environmentalists say omitting climate change leaves students unprepared.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - Oklahoma's oil industry is spending millions on science lessons for public schools. But environmentalists say omitting climate change leaves students unprepared. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/11/535653913/heres-what-the-oil-industry-is-teaching-oklahomas-students

item.title: Trump's Budget Plan Proposes Cuts To Great Lakes Restoration Projects
item.description: July 10, 2017 - President Trump's 2018 budget plan eliminates millions for Great Lakes restoration. What does that mean for projects across the Great Lakes, including research on harmful algae and Asian carp prevention efforts? NPR looks at the most important programs in each lake that could be targeted.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 10, 2017 - President Trump's 2018 budget plan eliminates millions for Great Lakes restoration. item.title: Pain Before Pleasure Makes The Pleasure Even Better, Study Finds
item.description:
July 10, 2017 - A study from the University of Kentucky shows that doing something virtuous can make indulging later even more pleasurable.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/07/10/536392970/pain-before-pleasure-makes-the-pleasure-even-better-study-finds
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Dads Respond Differently To Daughters Than To Sons, Study Finds
item.description: July 10, 2017 - Researchers from Emory University, using functional MRIs to measure fathers' brains, found that they had different biological reactions to their daughters' faces than to their sons'.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 10, 2017 - Researchers from Emory University, using functional MRIs to measure fathers' brains, found that they had different biological reactions to their daughters' faces than to their sons'. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/10/536392871/dads-respond-differently-to-daughters-than-to-sons-study-finds

item.title: NASA Spacecraft Gets Up Close With Jupiter's Great Red Spot
item.description: July 10, 2017 - NASA's Juno spacecraft will fly directly over the Great Red Spot, a swirling storm on Jupiter, on Monday. Scientists are hoping to gain a better understanding of the storm and why it persists.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 10, 2017 - NASA's Juno spacecraft will fly directly over the Great Red Spot, a swirling storm on Jupiter, on Monday. Scientists are hoping to gain a better understanding of the storm and why it persists. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/10/535977281/nasa-spacecraft-gets-up-close-with-jupiters-great-red-spot

item.title: Women With High-Risk Pregnancies Are More Likely To Develop Heart Disease
item.description: July 10, 2017 - Women who develop diabetes or high blood pressure during pregnancy, or whose babies are born prematurely, often are unaware of their own increased risk of heart disease later. So are their doctors.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 10, 2017 - Women who develop diabetes or high blood pressure during pregnancy, or whose babies are born prematurely, often are unaware of their own increased risk of heart disease later. So are their doctors. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/10/535644276/women-with-high-risk-pregnancies-are-more-likely-to-develop-heart-disease

item.title: The Call-In: Physician-Assisted Dying
item.description: July 9, 2017 - It's been a year since California passed its right-to-die law. JoNel Aleccia of Kaiser Health News discusses the change and Lisa Crawford talks about her family's experience.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 9, 2017 - It's been a year since California passed its right-to-die law. JoNel Aleccia of Kaiser Health News discusses the change and Lisa Crawford talks about her family's experience. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/09/536263078/the-call-in-physician-assisted-dying

item.title: Young Black Girls Face 'Adultification'
item.description: July 9, 2017 - A new study shows that black girls are viewed as less innocent and in need of less protection than white girls. A Martinez speaks to two authors of the study: Rebecca Epstein and Dr. Jamilia Blake.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 9, 2017 - A new study shows that black girls are viewed as less innocent and in need of less protection than white girls. A Martinez speaks to two authors of the study: Rebecca Epstein and Dr. Jamilia Blake. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/09/536263057/young-black-girls-face-adultification
